comments.commentBody:
Medical profession serves the pain and suffering of people. Its natural for people to get agitated and threatning when they precive neglect. The more ill-informed they are the more violent they become.
In US most common threat known daily to doctors is verbal, threats of lawsuits and lawyers (and you hear them very often)
During my many years of Medical training and practice in the city, I have known patients and relatives who get threatning often, and violent sometimes, whenever the patient's condition slides.
All NYC city hospitals have NYPD hospital police as guards and until recntly some had lockups within the hospital buildings.

comments.userLocation: Lewis Family Farm, Essex, New York
comments.commentBody:
Civilization and Its Discontents, here and there.

Let's put it where it is. China is troubled. We are deeply troubled. We are troubled differently, and our troubles relate.

The Chinese government seeks counsel from US doctors of senior status - and pays a modest fortune for advice. They fly them over.

Given the issues and the magnitude of the problem, there is little chance the advice given will or can translate into meaningful progress.

Think about it.

If things deteriorate, violence threatens in and out of the cities.

If things improve markedly, they will not be able to keep the lid on expectations.

Trouble either way. It's a dictatorship.

If deflation crushes us, US imports will drop and China will find herself seeking markets at a time of deep contraction. It's exports will flop.

The US dollar is not behaving well against the basket. China's reserves are held in US dollars. She cannot change this.

In all this, we are worrying about health care violence at the fringe.

China is worrying about water.

It's time to strip China to what's there, and what's not there.

Deflation sucks all, regardless location.

We have deflation, and China believes this makes sense, if that matters.

Our deflation will prove intractable for China.

Our health care will prove intractable for us.
This actually makes the US healthcare system sound comparatively less bad. I don't remember the last time I've read something like that.

Palin is not a Governor. She quit that job half way through it. She has the best job in the world. She just says idiotic drivel and gets paid hundreds of thousands of dollars for it, and is given a credibility that is not earned or valid beyond the teabagging minority.

The Sarah Palin Brand of quitter politician should be meaningless--and toxic--if it endorses other candidates. Who really empowered this ignoranus? Bill Kristol, whose cruise ship full of neo-cons she had welcomed with open arms to Alaska, helping the far-right of the party pressure McCain into making her his running mate (and thereby losing the election)?

It's Sarah first, not "Country First." She couldn't care less if the country becomes a failed state if she stays famous and gets rich from being a brand.

Since when do Republicans -- let alone Boehner the Orange -- care about their constituents?  They only care about enriching the rich people who enrich their campaign funds.  They would be Ok if the US was sold wholesale to the Chinese.  As long as they got their cut of the profits.

BP should look into the many 27-hole "munis" ...

These three 9-hole courses rotate players to different combinations of nines to give golfers a variety of 18-hole rounds on the same course...

...AND permit us to play just 9 holes like BP is looking for...and even WALK them if we'd like before the carts take over.

...if he's ever in the neighborhood, I'd be happy to share with him an early morning 9-hole walk unspoiled on my local muni here in SoFla....

Auggie, I sure hope that wife is not getting any kind of government assistance: that would be Marxist-socialist Obama care...against which you rail all day and all night. (It is actually fine with me if she gets the assistance to which she is entitled.) You can't have it both ways. I think you need to quit hogging the computer and let her get some resumes and applications out. Be sure Ben Stein (neo-con darling) doesn't have input. He says she is unemployed because she is an unpleasant person.
Did you hear that?  I think that was the first brick falling out of the Sarah Palin "Wall of Dubious Celebrity".
Wrestlers -- and their wives -- are the epitome of the Republican candidate:   total frauds who are able to fool the gullible.

More disturbing than the possibility that these teens are shallow, stupid, vain, and so on, is the near-certainty that they are driven by some degree of self-loathing. What someone looks like is a mysterious chemistry of personality, physical looks, happiness, and more. Barring the repair of a serious medical condition, I don't see where it's worth medically treating one's looks.

Doctors take some responsibility for this: My preschool age child has a couple minor anomalies in his appearance that his eye doctor repeatedly recommended we repair surgically. His ENT also asked us about surgery. Both procedures would be elective, cash transactions. Our child is beautiful, and we have switched doctors. We went to these guys for medical treatment, not a hair-salon-like upsell.

No one blinks an eye when kids get braces--and dentists have told me point blank that straight teeth offer no advantages unless they are easier to clean than before. It would probably kill the media to say that perhaps these procedures should be taken case by case.

Everyone seems to know what's best for minors, except for minors of course.

I had a nose job in my 20s and I'm very happy with the results. I went into the procedure with a healthy set of expectations and was not let down. However, thinking back to my teenage self, my expectations would have been much different. I would have expected grandiose changes in my social life. Perhaps waiting is the best option. With time, we have a chance to garner a better interpretation of ourselves.

I had figured out the top, then the lower right. It took a while, but I finally got that the middle was a rebus of what i knew had to be 9 words starting with D, and somehow making EDITH and EDITS, etc. Loved all that. Still, the lower left sat blank, except for the erroneous EAST.or WESTEGG. Thanks to Arthur118 for the slap to the forehead moment. Clever puzzle. Used up all the time saved by zipping through yesterday's. And then some.

I'd undoubtedly fume much as Ms. Blades does.  But there's a wonderful story (recounted, I believe, by Bob Woodward in "The Brethren") about how Thurgood Marshall defused an analogous situation.  Seems that from time to time visitors to the Supreme Court would get a little lost and wind up in the "Justices Only" elevator.  Mistaking Marshall for the elevator operator, they would say something like "Third floor, please."  To which Marshall would reply "Yowza-yowza" and cheerfully take the poor dupes wherever they asked.  Was all he could do to keep a straight face until he made it back to chambers and started cracking up.  One can only yearn for such grace and humor.

Unfortunately there are parents who really don't know how to be parents.  They are unwilling or unable to make decisions in the best interest of their child, and instead give in to any request the child might have.   Parenting requires hard, sometimes unpopular, decisions.

I wouldn't say "Lighten up" since being asked something about which you are sensitive is both painful and annoying. However, I also wouldn't say that people who say "Lighten up" about this situation are necessarily out of touch with racial issues (or age issues or adoption issues). It just happens that people respond differently to situations, crisis or otherwise. Some laugh it off with humor, others pretend to laugh it off with humor; some use it to teach, others use it to vent anger.

The question "Is s/he yours?" has been asked to loads of parents and nannies. This is one of the many, many situations that arise when people decide to start a relationship and raise a family. It wasn't meant to be easy, and there are plenty of people who are going to make sure we all earn our "Parenting Badges" to pin to our sashes.

As Nicole said, she has chosen to address it positively. Not to hide from the issue, not to slap the questioner in the face (that'll teach them!), not to alienate. I think there was a lot of misreading or non-reading of the entire piece.

And to #88, Betsy: As an adoptee who didn't look a heck of a lot like the rest of her taller, lighter, thinner family, just saying "Yes, she is" would be great. But it's also your story, and as you said NOT saying anything about being adopted could be interpreted (especially by a moody, hormone-ridden teenager) as negative. I think that "Yes, she is. We adopted her (or She adopted us)" sums it up pretty nicely. The most important thing is that you are comfortable with how you respond.

On the plus side - botox doesn't last fore ever.
And perhaps the perceived problem will just mature away.
I think the teenager looked better before she had the treatment. The reduced jaw line looks like she is under some kind of tension- not normal.
Woman and girls like to look good, period.  This is reality, deal with it.
I love square jaws. It makes me cringe that someone might reverse such a desirable trait! (Maybe there's a plastic surgery to give me a squarer jaw; I suppose there is: implants.)

I have a hard time even reading this story about the "stress" this wealthy and privileged family has to endure. But I know the Carnegie's can afford to send their loved ones to the best doctors and send them to the best clinics or treatment centers for however long they need it. They can afford the costly drugs they need. Plus they won't have to worry about their loved ones ending up destitute and homeless because they can't be employed.

However, on the other hand, the rest of us have to struggle to afford just the insurance for our ourselves or our loved ones with mental illness. And the insurance hardly covers the necessary treatments. The doctors we can afford are overworked, drugs are expensive, and in-patient treatment is short term only. As for our loved ones who can't work because of mental illness, it's difficult to get them on Social Security Disability, and even then, it pays very little, so their care often falls to those who love them (if they are lucky enough to have loved ones who can help).

So forgive me if I don't want to read a story about the "stress" of being wealthy AND mentally ill.

I've only read a few of the comments so this may be redundant in some way. I am not offended by "is he/she yours" questions. I ask that question myself - perhaps every weekend at some point at the library, park, pool. It's an innocent question that opens up the conversation about the child. I am totally secure in my position as my kids' mom so it honestly does not faze me nor strike me as odd when someone says, "Is he/she your child?" I don't assume they are asking for any reason other than to say: "She dropped her dinosaur by the slide" or "He seems to be having trouble with his shoes."

I am lucky to live in an urban area that is home to many, many multiracial unions and also has a very high rate of international and interracial adoptions. I see more families in which the kids don't clearly resemble the parents than the other way around. I think a lot of us are used to not being able to pin a child on a given family tree based on appearances.

Perhaps most of my comfort results from my being a 40-something biracial woman. I was a biracial child living in a white universe long before it was anywhere near common. I had people gawk at my dad (is he abducting her?) Stare at my mom (is she the babysitter?) I had classmates say I must be adopted because two people from different races cannot make babies together. On and on. The only time I remember being bothered was in ninth grade when Becky raised her hand and asked our social studies teacher if I was lying about the fact that I was my parents' bio daughter. That wasn't so bad. What was so bad was my social studies teacher (who knew both my parents really well) couldn't handle the question and changed the subject, put Becky in detention and added to my mystique, which kindled the gossip fires all over school.

Don't overthink this stuff.

Maybe this is an economic class issue. We were plain middle class people when my son was 13. He and his buddies at the local public high school all wanted jobs and helped one another to find simple after-school work. They seemed to enjoy their jobs and to benefit from working beyond the cash. There seemed to be social benefits as well in dealing with adults other than family and teachers.

William McCloskey, Pittsburgh

@#30

cgwolf: Your physician needed to "get approval" for your Botox injections merely for insurance approval reasons, not for any unforeseen medical risks or other implied obstructive reasons (in comparison to "easy access and frivolous use of Botox" for cosmetic reasons). If you were to pay on the spot for the Botox pain treatment, just as cosmetic patients almost always pay "out of pocket" for their therapies, your physician would have gladly injected Botox at your first visit. Likewise, if a doctor sought to get an insurer's approval for the cosmetic injection of jaw Botox (claiming justification by citing treatment for TMJ Syndrome, migraines or Bruxism, also known as teeth grinding), the waiting period prior to getting the Botox treatment would have taken a month or so.
